name: cni
description: Container Network Interface - networking for Linux containers
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: You can see at https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/releases that we create "rc" versions prior to release.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: You can see at https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/releases that each version has a number such as 0.3.1, 0.6.0.
version_tags_justification: Each version is stamped with a git tag.
report_process_justification: Users should submit bug reports at https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/issues/new
build_justification:
The main way this repo is consumed is by source code, as is customary in Go, but there is a build script
https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/blob/master/scripts/release.sh
build_common_tools_justification: Uses the standard Go build tool 'go build'.
build_floss_tools_justification:
Uses the standard Go build tool 'go build'. 
Go is MIT licenced https://github.com/golang/go/blob/master/LICENSE
test_justification:
Runs Go tests via Travis https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/blob/master/.travis.yml
Tests are called via the 'go test' command from https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/blob/master/test.sh
test_invocation_justification: Tests are invocable using 'go test', e.g. https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/blob/master/libcni/libcni_suite_test.go
delivery_mitm_justification: CNI itself is only accessible on the machine it runs on
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: No vulnerabilities have been found in this way, to date.
general_comments:
CNI is a small but critical interface layer used by Kubernetes, CloudFoundry and similar projects.
The main repo contains the specification and library; https://github.com/containernetworking/plugins/ which holds the "base plugins" should also be considered part of CNI.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: CI is run via Travis via Travis https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/blob/master/.travis.yml triggered on every commit
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: Documentation is in English in https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/blob/master/README.md and https://github.com/containernetworking/cni/blob/master/SPEC.md
crypto_used_network_justification: CNI is an interface between two programs on the same machine; all information is passed via stdout/stdin and no crypto is used.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: Hyperledger Ursa
description: A shared cryptographic library that enables people (and projects) to avoid duplicating cryptographic work across projects, increasing security in the process.
contribution_justification: https://github.com/hyperledger/ursa/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/hyperledger/ursa/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://docs.rs/ursa/0.3.5/ursa/
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Github issues and pull requests plus git branches and git tags are used for enabling collaborative review of interim versions and point releases.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
report_process_justification:
https://github.com/hyperledger/ursa/issues
https://lists.hyperledger.org/g/ursa/topics

bug reports may be submitted via Github issues and/or the Hyperledger Ursa mailing list
report_responses_justification: Github issues are always commented on by the maintainers and either closed or assigned.
enhancement_responses_justification: Same as bug reports. Submitted as either Github pull requests or as issues.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: The Hyperledger security@ mailing list handles vulnerability reporting and has an SLA for responding within 48 hours of the initial report.
build_justification: Ursa uses Rust's cargo build tool to build the software.
build_common_tools_justification: Github Actions and Rust Cargo are used.
build_floss_tools_justification: Ursa is a project written in Rust and uses the open source Rust build tools.
test_justification: Ursa uses cargo test to run the test suites
test_invocation_justification:
https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/commands/cargo-test.html
Ursa uses cargo test to run the test suites
test_policy_justification: The pull request review process checks for tests to test any major new functionality.
warnings_strict_justification: Rust cargo build is maximally strict with warnings. Ursa uses that for building.
know_secure_design_justification: The maintainers of Ursa have the required knowledge and experience.
know_common_errors_justification: The maintainers of Ursa have the required knowledge and experience.
crypto_published_justification: This is the entire raison d'être of Ursa.
crypto_call_justification: Ursa provides safe wrappers around well-known open source crypto libraries.
crypto_working_justification: The cargo features systems used to build Ursa implements these checks.
crypto_pfs_justification: Ursa uses libsodium and AEAD constructs for this.
crypto_random_justification: Ursa has selectable PRNG's, all of which are cryptographically secure.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: No known CVE's against Ursa yet. If there were, they would be fixed and disclosed via the Github Security Advisories.
static_analysis_justification: Rust clippy is used in the AZP build pipeline.
static_analysis_often_justification: The AZP build checks and tests are run on every pull request and push.
dynamic_analysis_justification: The rust test suites do this.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Ursa is written in Rust which is not a memory unsafe language.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Ursa uses assert! and panic! macros in many places.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: The cargo features systems used to build Ursa prevents this.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: Github issues and pull requests are used to file bug reports and allow for other people to comment on the code.
hardening_justification:
https://users.rust-lang.org/t/what-security-features-are-implemented-by-rustc/19757

The Rust compiler compiles libraries that are portable and support randomized linking to harden the resulting binary in production environments.
crypto_used_network_justification: Ursa has no networking protocols implemented.
crypto_tls12_justification: Ursa has no networking protocols implemented.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: Ursa has no networking protocols implemented.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: Ursa has no networking protocols implemented.
hardened_site_justification: https://github.com/hyperledger/ursa
implementation_languages: Rust, Groovy, Python, Dockerfile, C, Shell, Makefile
documentation_current_justification: Generated documentation from the source: https://docs.rs/ursa/0.3.5/ursa/
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: Ursa is documented and published using Confluence and Github, both of which are accessible web sites.
internationalization_justification: Rust's automatic documentation generation process supports documentation in any language.
sites_password_security_justification: Ursa uses Github which meets these criteria.
maintenance_or_update_justification: Ursa keeps all releases available and explains when/how upgrades should be done via the release notes.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio:
https://github.com/hyperledger/ursa/blob/master/SECURITY.md

All security reports are published using Github Security Advisories which properly credits the reporter(s).
coding_standards_justification:
https://github.com/hyperledger/ursa/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

The rust compiler enforces a particular coding style used by all rust projects.
coding_standards_enforced_justification:
https://github.com/hyperledger/ursa/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

The rust compiler enforces a particular coding style used by all rust projects.
build_standard_variables_justification: Azure pipelines uses docker to support specific build settings.
build_preserve_debug_justification: Ursa uses rust cargo to build and install. It defaults to a debug version of the library and requires --release to be passed to strip out debugging information.
build_non_recursive_justification: Rust cargo is used and supports workspaces with recursive builds.
installation_standard_variables_justific: Cargo install knows the conventions for all of the different platforms.
installation_development_quick_justifica: Cargo install handles all of this.
external_dependencies_justification:
https://github.com/hyperledger/ursa/blob/master/Cargo.toml

The Cargo.toml files in the repo are machine readable dependency trees.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: Cargo update automates updating the dependencies of Ursa as needed.
interfaces_current_justification: All of the Rust crates and the system libraries used by Ursa are FLOSS.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: AZP is run on every push.
implement_secure_design_justification: The Rust programming language already embodies these design principles and they are enforced at compile time. The maintainers that review the pull requests also have the expertise needed to evaluate the secure design principles as they apply to any code change.
input_validation_justification: There are no inputs from untrusted sources. Ursa only depends on well known and tested FLOSS crypto libraries and tools.
crypto_credential_agility_justification: Ursa supports TEE and other secure key storage techniques.
contributors_unassociated_justification:
https://github.com/hyperledger/ursa/graphs/contributors

The top 10 contributors to Ursa are all unassociated and work for different organizations.
require_2FA_justification: Ursa is managed by Github with 2FA enabled.
secure_2FA_justification: Ursa is managed by Github and their 2FA mechanism meets this requirement.
security_review_justification: Hyperledger Ursa had a security review as part of the security audit of Hyperledger Iroha that uses it.

name: skipper
description: An HTTP router and reverse proxy for service composition, including use cases like Kubernetes Ingress
interact_justification:
https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
and we have an additional tutorial for how to develop https://opensource.zalando.com/skipper/tutorials/development/
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification:
https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md shows the coding standard using gofmt as it is common in the Go community.
Additionally we provide a more in depth tutorial on how to develop https://opensource.zalando.com/skipper/tutorials/development/
license_location_justification:
Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/LICENSE>.

In general the software is Apache License 2.0, but software below pathmux/ directory is MIT license.
floss_license_justification:
https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/LICENSE shows the license information.

In general the software is Apache License 2.0, but software below pathmux/ directory is MIT license.  The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
Some documentation basics file contents found.
user docs: https://opensource.zalando.com/skipper
developer docs: https://godoc.org/github.com/zalando/skipper
documentation_interface_justification: Godoc provides the API docs for library users: https://godoc.org/github.com/zalando/skipper
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification:
Every PR is reviewed and can be commented in a team view using Github PR.
Github can also compare 2 commits in diff views.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification:
Every merge to master with a successful build in travis-ci creates a new, unique, incremented git tag increasing the patch version.  
Auto incremented tags: https://github.com/zalando/skipper/tags
Releases providing release notes and docker image: https://github.com/zalando/skipper/releases
release_notes_justification: https://github.com/zalando/skipper/releases are used to add a human-readable summary
report_process_justification: Bug reports can be applied at https://github.com/zalando/skipper/issues and the process is described in https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#report-a-bug
report_responses_justification: https://github.com/zalando/skipper/issues is used and we have an internal rule to respond to every issue within one week.
enhancement_responses_justification: https://github.com/zalando/skipper/issues is used and we have an internal rule to respond to every issue within one week.
build_floss_tools_justification: Makefile and the Go compiler are FLOSS tools required to build the project.
test_justification:
The Go compiler is FLOSS tool required to test the project.
Optional is the Makefile to help to test the project, which is also FLOSS.
test_invocation_justification: Makefile and Go's stdlib test suite can be used to invoke the tests. Both are very common in Go projects.
test_most_justification: A GH project badge https://codecov.io/gh/zalando/skipper shows 70% coverage.
test_policy_justification: For major (core) changes there is a sentence "Every change in core has to have tests included and should be a non breaking change." at https://opensource.zalando.com/skipper/tutorials/development/#core
tests_are_added_justification:
For every non trivial change we write tests, for example https://github.com/zalando/skipper/pull/869/files
We also have documented how to write tests https://opensource.zalando.com/skipper/reference/development/#writing-tests
tests_documented_added_justification: https://opensource.zalando.com/skipper/reference/development/#writing-tests explains how to write test in the how to develop a filter https://opensource.zalando.com/skipper/reference/development/#how-to-develop-a-filter
warnings_justification: Go is in general memory safe, additionally we use a `pre-commit` Makefile target running in travisCI to make sure Go fmt, Go build, Go vet, staticcheck and tests are successfully running. All these tools are FLOSS tools and can be run locally without CI.
warnings_fixed_justification: Merge to master can not be applied if a warning from one of the tools: Go fmt, Go build, Go vet (https://golang.org/cmd/vet/), staticcheck (https://staticcheck.io/) and Go tests are failing
warnings_strict_justification:
Merge to master can not be applied if a warning from one of the tools: Go fmt, Go build, Go vet (https://golang.org/cmd/vet/), staticcheck (https://staticcheck.io/) and Go tests are failing
Exceptions from staticcheck that we allow are commented in the Makefile at https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/Makefile#L96-L101
know_secure_design_justification: primary developers understanding the mentioned design are https://github.com/aryszka and https://github.com/szuecs
know_common_errors_justification: primary developers understanding the mentioned design are https://github.com/aryszka and https://github.com/szuecs
crypto_published_justification:
Use Go libraries and not implement ourselves. 

The project uses crypto/tls t terminate and validate TLS connections and crypto/rand crypto/cipher crypto/aes golang.org/x/crypto/scrypt to enable key rotation and add a stateful cookie to support OpenID Connect auth code flow as documented in the spec https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#AuthRequest. The project uses AES256 GCM to encrypt the session cookie after successful OpenID Connect and protects from CSRF https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-Site_Request_Forgery_(CSRF)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet#Encrypted_Token_Pattern with an encrypted query to validate the redirect request is coming from us.

The project uses `crypto/md5` only in tests to generate test content.
crypto_call_justification: Everything related to cryptography is using Go standard library
crypto_keylength_justification: TLS provided by the Go standard library and AES 256 GCM
crypto_working_justification:
TLS provided by the Go standard library and AES 256 GCM.
MD5 is only used to generate time dependent random content in tests.
crypto_pfs_justification: TLS provided by the Go standard library
crypto_password_storage_justification: User authentication with username password is only support by Open ID Connect (we do not store external users username and password) and Basic Auth. If a user choose to use basic auth the file format used is htpasswd as in Apache2 webserver and basic auth is implemented by https://github.com/abbot/go-http-auth which supports bcrypt.
crypto_random_justification: We use Go standard library crypto/rand to generate cryptographically secure random numbers if needed.
delivery_unsigned_justification: We always use https to get cryptographic signatures.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: There was no security vulnerability reported
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica:
There was no security vulnerability reported.
Our process involve the technical security team of the company Zalando SE.
static_analysis_justification:
We use Go vet and staticcheck enforced by a required passing CI pipeline before merge to master.
Master is a protected branch that requires a successful Travis CI pipeline run.
Go vet (https://golang.org/cmd/vet/), staticcheck (https://staticcheck.io/) are both FLOSS tools
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j:
Go is a memory safe language and the software does not implement features that can be attacked by common vulnerabilities for example SQL injection or XSS.
We use go vet and staticcheck https://staticcheck.io/ that checks for coding best practice and finds common errors that could lead to vulnerabilities.
We use gosec https://github.com/securego/gosec to check for common security problems in our CI pipeline 
Both tools are run by our CI pipeline and are mandatory to be successful, before merge is allowed.
static_analysis_fixed_justification:
There was no exploitable vulnerability discovered with static code analysis, yet.
https://github.com/zalando/skipper/issues/914 shows a run of a not yet enabled static analysis tool, but all issues reported are not relevant as these are only used for tests, wrong findings by the tool or the user has to opt-in and run the software with `-insecure` flag.
static_analysis_often_justification: static source code analysis are ran as pre-commit hook enforced by the required CI pipeline before merge to master can be done.
dynamic_analysis_justification: There is no common dynamic analysis tools available for Go.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Go is in general memory safe and we do not use CGO nor Go standard library `unsafe` to circumvent memory safety provided by the runtime
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: We do not have dynamic code analysis tools running
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: We do not have dynamic code analysis tools running
crypto_weaknesses_justification:
TLS provided by the Go standard library and AES 256 GCM.
MD5 is only used to generate time dependent random content in tests.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: The project uses a public visible TravisCI https://travis-ci.org/zalando/skipper that runs tests automatically and is required to pass before merge to master
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: Credentials and private keys stored in the repository are only used in tests and are clearly marked as test only
english_justification:
All documentation is written in English
user docs: https://opensource.zalando.com/skipper
developer docs: https://godoc.org/github.com/zalando/skipper
issues for bug reports are applied in English https://github.com/zalando/skipper/issues
PR discussions are also in English https://github.com/zalando/skipper/pulls
crypto_used_network_justification: The software uses the defaults of the Go language which comes with sane defaults.
crypto_tls12_justification: TLS supported by the Go core stdlib and supports TLS version 1.2
crypto_certificate_verification_justific:
TLS is supported by the used Go core stdlib and supports TLS cert verification. 
Cert validation is enabled by default.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: TLS is supported by the used Go core stdlib and it will not send http headers before TLS certs are verified
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification:
As library user you can use `go get`, which is common in the Go community and a core feature.
As binary user you can use Go build, which is common in the Go community and a core feature.
As docker user you can use the provided docker containers listed in our releases: https://github.com/zalando/skipper/releases
implementation_languages: Go, Shell, Makefile, Yacc, PHP, Dockerfile
dco_justification: DCO is required for all PRs before merge to master, see https://github.com/zalando/skipper/pulls
roles_responsibilities_justification: https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md describes the responsibility of the key role maintainer and contributor.
access_continuity_justification: https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/MAINTAINERS all maintainers have the right to review and accept PRs with 4 eyes.
documentation_current_justification: Documentation gaps and errors are treated as defects in our issue tracker marked via label https://github.com/zalando/skipper/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Adocumentation
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: The project is first class library and command line proxy. For docs we depend on mkdocs and Github rendering markdown for documentation.
internationalization_justification: Skipper does not produce text output for end-users
sites_password_security_justification: project sites do not store passwords
maintenance_or_update_justification: We provide everything required in release notes https://github.com/zalando/skipper/releases
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: Report via E-Mail to security team https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/SECURITY.md
coding_standards_enforced_justification: It is documented that [gofmt](https://golang.org/cmd/gofmt/) is used and it is enforced via CI pipeline which is required to run and return with exit 0 before merge to master.
build_standard_variables_justification: We use the normal Go compiler and linker suite and you are free to pass LDFLAGS or compiler flags to it.
build_preserve_debug_justification: We use the normal Go compiler and linker suite and you are free to pass debug flags to it to get DWARF symbols.
build_non_recursive_justification: We build all packages by passing go files to the build process https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/Makefile and link to a static library or binaries in the provided Makefile.
build_repeatable_justification: Building the software relies on the Go compiler which builds in a repeatable process.
installation_standard_variables_justific: `go install`, which is common in the Go community and a core feature of Go, honors GOBIN, which can be set by users to set the DESTDIR of the binary output.
installation_development_quick_justifica: You can use `go get -t`, which is common in the Go community and a core feature.
external_dependencies_justification: We use Go modules a feature from core Go: https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/go.mod
updateable_reused_components_justificati:
We met 1. and 2., because we use Go modules a feature from core Go: https://github.com/zalando/skipper/blob/master/go.mod
With Go you can list dependencies:
GO111MODULE=on go list -m -u all
interfaces_current_justification: We use mandatory checks like `staticcheck` and `go vet` that will point out deprecated functions
automated_integration_testing_justificat: We use travis-ci for all opened PRs and it is mandatory to pass before merge to master
regression_tests_added50_justification: All relevant bug fixes have tests included, that will run for all opened pull requests (PR)
test_statement_coverage80_justification:
We have 70% test coverage, because we do not cover the less relevant sections.
TODO: increase to 80%
implement_secure_design_justification:
Default route is do not allow and users need to change that before using this software.
Access filters disallow access on all errors
input_validation_justification: Parsing data from untrusted sources is done by the Go net/http package and not rebuild
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: TLS connection settings can be chosen as Go supports.
crypto_credential_agility_justification: Credentials are not bundled in the code and needs to be passed by the user, such that it can be updated or replaced without code changes.

name: GRASS GIS
description: GRASS GIS, commonly referred to as GRASS (Geographic Resources Analysis Support System), is a free and open source Geographic Information System (GIS) software suite used for geospatial data management and analysis, image processing, graphics and maps production, spatial modeling, and visualization. GRASS GIS is currently used in academic and commercial settings around the world, as well as by many governmental agencies and environmental consulting companies. It is a founding member of the Open Source Geospatial Foundation (OSGeo).
